abstracts.cdata!:
The FIDP objective was to promote the
            development of NBFIs, in particular, and investment
            financing, in general, on a sustainable basis that would
            contribute to improvements in the quality of intermediation
            and the speed and efficiency of industrial growth in
            Bangladesh. Project ratings are as follows : project outcome
            was satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance, satisfactory; borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. The project offers a number of
            important lessons with respect to a) training needs
            assessment at project design or early in the implementation
            stage permits efficient structuring of training events,
            fully utilizing training funds, organizational synergies,
            advance coordination among all government agencies to
            benefit from the training, and maximizing efficiency while
            lowering costs; for projects with innovative components, a
            separate communications program outlined and budgeted at
            project design phase can improve project understanding and
            acceptability; the project failed to foresee the training
            needs of FAPAD, the supreme audit body; project complexity
            raises risks of delivery failure; reforms can increase their
            chances of being implemented if they deal with a narrow set
            of issues, involving a minimal number of government agencies
            (possibly a single agency).

5081669.majtheme: Rule of law,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Institutions Development
            Project (FIDP) will promote the development of non-bank
            financial institutions (NBFIs) in particular, and,
            investments as a whole. Since the potential for NBFIs risk
            of contagion exists, rigorous measures will be applied. The
            project consists of two main components: 1) The resource
            mobilization component will aim at simplifying market
            regulations to facilitate bond and security issues, creating
            and developing market oriented mechanisms. Rules and
            procedures for bonds/debentures will be developed and
            implemented, raising funds and strengthening marketing of
            government treasury bonds. Both the Bank of Bangladesh and
            the Securities Exchange Commission will receive training on
            debt instruments, and, reforms will be implemented on the
            government's national saving schemes. Furthermore, this
            component will develop procedures for a secondary treasury
            bond/bill market. 2) The component to strengthen financial
            institutions will create the Credit, Bridge and Standby
            Facility (CBSF), to encourage term financing, through a more
            efficient financial system. The CBSF will, not only
            facilitate funding to NBFIs, and financial institutions, but
            will be institutionally strengthened through management and
            financial technical assistance. The financial
            institutions' capacity, will be enhanced through
            business planning, and resource management. This component
            will also revise CBSFs mechanisms.
